more.title: A long-acting HIV drug arrives in Zimbabwe for some at highest risk
more.description: Zimbabwe is one of the world's first countries to roll out lenacapavir, a long-acting HIV prevention drug that is administered only twice a year. It offers new hope for high-risk groups struggling with adherence to daily prevention pills. Early recipients, including sex workers, say the injectable drug reduces stigma and improves convenience. Health officials describe the drug as key for vulnerable populations that also include adolescent girls and young women. However, experts warn that funding constraints and clinic capacity could limit its impact. While sharply reduced pricing for poorer countries has been welcomed, advocates stress that affordability alone will not ensure success.

more.title: A long-acting HIV drug arrives in Zimbabwe for some at highest risk
more.description: Zimbabwe is one of the world's first countries to roll out lenacapavir, a long-acting HIV prevention drug that is administered only twice a year.

more.title: A Long-Acting HIV Drug Arrives in Zimbabwe for Some at Highest Risk
more.description: HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) — Young women, mothers holding babies and some men lined up in a dusty field on the outskirts of Zimbabwe’s capital, Harare. They came for injections of a new HIV prevention drug launched in the country on Thursday, one that only needs to be administered twice a year.
